Fill the blank spaces with the most appropriate of options A-E:

The armed robbers stabbed the driver …. the back
explanation:
prepositions are all connectors. 

In this context "In" is defined as inside an area, moving from a point outside to a point inside.

"On" is used to indicate position, usually indicating that something is on top of something else.

A stab in the back would mean, a stab from the outer area to the inner area. Option A is correct

Fill the blank spaces with the most appropriate of options A-E:
Chike, who plays in the first eleven, is an expert …. dribbling
explanation:
'At' as a Preposition is a word that joins a noun, pronoun, or noun phrases and makes each sentence complete. It is used in a sentence to indicate a location, direction, time, describe an activity, or sometimes, to introduce an object.

In this sentence, it is used to indicate Chike’s activity (at dribbling). Hence the complete statement would read;

Chike, who plays in the first eleven, is an expert at dribbling

Fill the blank spaces with the most appropriate of options A-E:

X: How do you want to be paid? In cash or by cheque?

Y: They asked him .... in cash or by cheque
explanation:
Reported speech is when we tell someone what another person said. To do this, we can use direct speech or indirect speech. From the statement above, X made the speech while Y is reporting the speech. In reported speech, we do not have to quote the exact statement but report it in its past form and the auxiliary verb must always be changed. The correct reported speech by Y would be;

Y: They asked him whether he wanted to be paid in cash or by cheque.

The auxiliary verb 'be' was dropped and replaced with 'whether or if' as the case may be.
options: how he wanted to be paid
whether he wanted to be paid
how did he want to be paid

question:
Choose the word or phrase from options A - E which has the opposite in meaning to the underlined word or words in each sentences:
Never in the history of human conflict has so much been owed by so many to so few.
explanation: Never was so much owed by so many to so few" was a wartime speech made by the British prime minister Winston Churchill on 20 August 1940. The name stems from the specific line in the speech, Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few, referring to the ongoing efforts of the Royal Air Force crews who were at the time fighting the Battle of Britain, the pivotal air battle with the German Luftwaffe with Britain expecting an invasion. Pilots who fought in the battle have been known as The Few ever since; at times being specially commemorated on 15 September, "Battle of Britain Day".
options: Many people owed much money at the end of the war
A handful of people saved the lives of a nation
A few people did a lot of thingsgratis
This conflict caused the largest ransome ever demanded
Very little was owed by anyone to anybody
